choices.text: Ear is pulled upwards, backwards, syringe jet posterosuperiorly.
Ear is pulled downwards, backwards, syringe jet anterosuperiorly.
Ear is pulled upwards, forwards, syringe jet anterosuperiorly.
Ear is pulled downwards and forwards, syringe jet posterosuperiorly.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the procedure given below?
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the picture given above is called Ear syringing.

In this procedure, the pinna is pulled upwards, backwards, water is injected at body temperature through a syringe into the EAC along the posterosuperior wall.

The pressure of water builds up in EAC and wax comes out.

Complications of syringing:

  1. Vertigo
  2. rupture of TM
  3. Reactivation of otitis media.

Contraindications:

  1. acute inflammatory conditions of the external or middle ear.
  2. perforation of TM
  3. presence of a grommet
  4. History of ear surgery.

Key Takeaway :

Syringing done by pulling the ear upwards backwards and laterally making the whole EAC in a straight line.

questions.text: A 31-year-old female patient presented with complain of Bilateral impairment of hearing for past 3 years. On examination Bilateral tympanic membrane was normal and intact. Audiogram is suggestive of bilateral conductive hearing loss with 20 db air bone gap. Patient didn't have any past history of head injury. Impedance audiometry was performed which is given below. All of the following constitute a part treatment except?
questions.solution:
In the Chart given above the pressure inside middle ear is between -200to + 200 which is the normal range thus pressure is normal.

But the compliance is shown to be decreased in the chart. This is suggestive of Type As type of curve of impedance audiometry.

Type As type of curve is formed in conditions such as otosclerosis.

Treatment of otosclerosis includes Hearing Aids, tab sodium fluoride, and surgery like stapedectomy and stapedotomy. ( Options A,B & C)

Gentamicin systemic therapy or intratympanic injection is not used in otosclerosis .it is mainly used for chemical labyrinthectomy in cases of severe vertigo. Thus option D here is wrong option.

Option A : Hearing aid trials can be given to patients who are not willing for surgery or who are not fit for surgery.

Option B : In mature cases of otosclerosis surgery such as stapedectomy and stapedotomy are done. In these surgeries, stapes suprastructure is removed and a fenestration Is created in the stapes footplate. Incus and this Fenestration are connected by a prosthesis.

Option C : Tab Sodium fluoride is given in active cases of otosclerosis . NaF accelerates the maturation of active focus by increasing osteoblasts and decreasing osteoclasts.

Key Takeaway: Otosclerosis Management :

Active Cases - NaF

Mature Cases - Stapedetomy > Stapedectomy, Ddx - Risk of Fistula or Hearing Aids if Patient not willing for Surgery.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presented with complain of decreased hearing, tinnitus, and vertigo since 1 month. Her pure tone audiometry was performed which is shown below. Otoscope examination showed normal tympanic membrane. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given audiogram shows decreased air and bone conduction threshold with no air bone gap especially in lower frequencies, which is suggestive of low frequency sensorineural hearing loss. This pattern in audiogram is characteristic of Meniere's disease.

Option B : Otosclerosis mostly shows bilateral conductive hearing loss with a dip in the bone conduction threshold at 2000hz. This dip is known as Carhart's notch.

Option C : Ototoxicity shows decreased bone and air conduction threshold at the higher frequency level (down sloping audiogram) which indicates high frequency sensorineural hearing loss.

Option D : Noise induced hearing loss also shows air and bone conduction threshold decrease at higher frequency down sloping audiogram, with a characteristic dip at 4000hz known as Boiler notch.

Key Takeaway: Meniere's disease is characterized by Vertigo with SNHL which first affects low frequency so Upsloping audiogram is seen.

Audiogram Slopes :

Upsloping - Meniere's

Downsloping Ddx -

Ototoxicity - Past H/o Drug

Presbycusis - Elderly Patient

Noise induced - H/o Noise Trauma

Image reference: Research gate journal.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented with complain of not responding to any sound. He was found to be having severe sensorineural hearing loss. Cochlear implantation was done in this patient. Picture Is given below. What are the total number of electrodes present in the newer cochlear implant device?
questions.solution:
cochlear implant is the first artificial sense organ. It was invented by Dr William F House. It replaces the organ of corti.

Cochlear implant has an external component and an internal component.

External component: a microphone, a speech processor, and a transmitter coil.

Internal component consists of a receiver and an electrode array. The electrode array consists of 24 electrodes.

The surgeon places electrodes in the inner ear and done as early as 1 year of age.

Indications of Cochlear Implant:

  1. BL Severe to Profound Sensorineural Hearing Loss

Contraindications:

  1. Michel Aplasia
  2. Central Auditory lesion

Key Takeaway: Cochlear Implant done at 1 year of age in Severe to profound SNHL Through Round window into Scala Tympani and The electrode array consists of 24 electrodes.

choices.text: A patient with bilateral profound sensorineural hearing loss.
A patient with bilateral microtia, canal atresia and congenital hearing loss.
A patient with bilateral acoustic neuroma planned for surgery.

questions.text:
The device shown in the picture given below is called Bone anchored hearing aid.
This device can be used for which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Indications of Bone anchored hearing aid are:

  • Children with atresia of EAC or microtia and anotia. The reconstruction surgery of pinna of anotia/microtia is not done before 6 years.
  • Patients with MRM with large cavities as a result of which hearing aid is not possible.
  • Patient with chronically discharging ears as a result of which hearing is not possible
  • In a single deaf ear with no benefit from air conduction hearing aid.

Mechanism of BAHA: The implant vibrates the skull Bone. The bone carries vibrations that bypass the external and middle ear and travel directly to cochlear nerve.

Option A : A patient with bilateral profound sensorineural deafness should be managed by cochlear implant.

Option B : A patient with bilateral SOM is managed medically and if chronic then by Myringotomy and grommet insertion.

Option D : A patient with bilateral acoustic neuroma planned for surgery rehabilitation of hearing is done with auditory brainstem implant.

Key Takeaway: Children with External ear deformities such as microtia, Anotia are managed with BAHA as definite reconstructive surgeries are done after 6 years of age.

Image reference: Ear community website.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient had developed head injury due to road accident. He developed sudden onset of complete facial palsy. His CT Scan showed fracture of temporal bone on the right temporal bone. Which of the following is the best intervention here?
questions.solution:
Temporal bone fractures are of Two types based on their axis in reference to long axis of the petrous part of temporal bone. They are longitudinal and transverse fractures.

Features of longitudinal fractures are: They are more common, injury to tympanic membrane is more common, facial nerve injury is about 20%, vertigo is usually absent, csf otorrhoea is common.

Features of transverse fractures are: They are less common, injury to tympanic membrane is not present, facial nerve injury is common, vertigo is severe, CSF otorrhoea is not present.

Investigations : The investigation of choice for petrous part of temporal bone is HRCT temporal bone.

Management: In sudden onset and complete palsy which is seen in most of the cases, early exploration and decompression of facial nerve or nerve repair should be carried out immediately.

Delayed onset palsy , which might be because of surrounding oedema, should be treated with systemic steroids and watchful waiting. ( Options B , C , D )

Key Takeaway :

Image reference: Radiology key journal.

choices.text: Aberrant reinnervation of parasympathetic fibers of auriculotemporal nerve with sympathetic sweat glands.
Aberrant reinnervation of parasympathetic fibers of auriculotemporal nerve with greater superficial petrosal nerve.
Abnormal cross innervation of facial nerve with greater auricular nerve.
Abnormal cross innervation of facial nerve with auriculotemporal nerve.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient underwent parotid surgery. Following the surgery, she developed a complaint of sweating over the cheeks on the operated side when she chews the food. What is the reason for this complaint?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical picture shown above, the diagnosis in this case is Frey's syndrome.



Frey syndrome, also known as gustatory sweating. When the patient chews food, They develop sweating over the cheek skin over parotid gland.

Frey syndrome is because of injury and aberrant reinnervation of parasympathetic fibers of auriculotemporal nerve with sympathetic sweat glands fibers.

Treatment is injection of botulinum toxins injected periodically.

Key Takeaway:

Frey's syndrome is because of Post surgical injury and aberrant reinnervation of parasympathetic fibers of auriculotemporal nerve with sympathetic sweat glands fibers.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presented with right sided facial palsy. Her gross examination shows slight synkinesis, resting tone was normal, eye closure was complete but with full effort, mouth shows slight weakness with maximum effort. What is the House Blackman grade based on this?
questions.solution:
House Brackmann Grading Of Facial nerve Injury Depends on Forehead Lid Closure And Mouth Innervation as Depicted Below.

Key Takeaway:

choices.text: Dislodgement of short process of incus from fossa
Vertical descending part of facial nerve

questions.text: While doing posterior tympanotomy through facial recess (picture given below) there are chances of injury to all of the following structures except?
questions.solution:
Facial recess is an area on the posterior wall of the middle ear.

Facial recess is limited superiorly by fossa incudus, laterally by chorda tympani and medially by vertical part of facial segment. ( Options A, C & D )

Horizontal part of facial nerve is not related to facial recess area. The facial recess is the site where opening is made on the posterior wall to access the middle ear cavity through mastoid in Intact canal wall ear surgery. This is known as the posterior tympanotomy approach. ( Option B )

Key Takeaway: Posterior Tympanotomy Approach Damages Structure near Posterior wall Of Middle ear which Involves Facial Nerve Vertical part, Chorda Tympani and Incus.

Image reference: Research gate journal.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presented with complain of inability to close right eye, Deviation of angle of mouth, Dripping of saliva from angle of mouth. The following test was performed in the patient picture given below. Function of which of the following nerve is tested here?
questions.solution:
The patient in this case is suffering from Facial palsy. The test shown in the figure given above is called Schirmer test.

The first branch of facial nerve is Greater petrosal nerve. It arises from geniculate ganglion and goes to sphenopalatine ganglion and gives secretomotor fibers to lacrimal, nasal and palatine glands. It's section leads to dry eye which can be tested by Schirmer test with help of whatman filter paper.


Option B : Nerve to stapedius Injury result in hyperacusis and loss of stapedial Reflex.

Option C : Chorda Tympani Injury Results in Loss of Taste Sensation from Anterior 2/3rd of Tongue.

Option D : Lacrimal Nerve Injury leads to loss of lacrimal gland Secretion and Sensation.

Key Takeaway:


Image reference: American Academy of Ophthalmology.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presented with complaints of progressive facial weakness. MRI showed a facial nerve Schwannoma. What is the most common site of the above lesion?
questions.solution:
Schwannomas are rare nerve sheath tumours that can occur throughout the body, and are symptomatic based on location, size, and impingement on adjacent structures.

These tumours are often benign lesions and occur sporadically or from genetic conditions such as neurofibromatosis. Schwannomas may arise from peripheral nerves, gastrointestinal nerves, spinal nerve roots and cranial nerves.

Facial nerve Schwannomas arise from cranial nerve VII, commonly involving the geniculate ganglion, labyrinthine segment, and internal auditory canal.

While small lesions are asymptomatic, larger lesions can cause facial nerve paralysis, and facial spasms. Lesions in the internal auditory canal can cause hearing loss, tinnitus, vertigo, and otalgia.

High-resolution CT imaging and MRI imaging are useful for distinguishing between other pathologies that arise from the same region. High-resolution CT scans can show bony degeneration of nearby structures such as the labyrinth or ossicles.

MRI imaging shows hypo intensity on T1 imaging, and hyper intensity on T2 imaging. On T1 post contrast, enhancement can be homogenous or heterogeneous with cystic degeneration if the lesion is large. Nodular enhancement is commonly seen on facial nerve Schwannomas within the internal auditory canal.

Key Takeaway:

Facial Nerve and MC Part Involved -

Acoustic Neuroma / Viral Infection - Compression & Ischemia - Labyrinthine (Shortest & Narrowest)

Congenital Dehiscent FC - Tympanic / Horizontal

Surgical Facial Injury - Vertical / Mastoid Part.

choices.text: It is commonly seen in surfer hence known as surfer's ear.
It arises from Lateral part of bony external auditory canal.
It occurs due to prolonged exposure to cold water

questions.text: A 27-year-old male patient presented with complain of Bilateral decreased hearing and mild ear ache. On examination, multiple bony swellings were seen in both ears. Picture given below. All of the following are true about this condition except?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical picture and symptoms the diagnosis in this case is Exostosis of external auditory canal.

Exostosis is the most common benign tumour of the EAC. They develop as a result of reactive bone formation in response to exposure to cold water. (Option C) It is commonly seen in surfer hence known as surfer's ear. (Option A)

Site : Medial Wall of External Auditory Canal (Option B)

Clinical features: if large they can cause conductive hearing loss and wax impaction.

Management: if symptomatic, surgical removal by elevation of skin flap and drinking out of bone is Done. (Option D)

Key Takeaway:

Exostosis Aka Surfer's ears slowly progress to Benign bone growth dt Chronic Cold Exposure into Medial Wall of Bony EAC.

Image reference: CMAJ website.

choices.text: Fluctuating type of sensorineural hearing loss is seen.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with pulsatile tinnitus and progressive deafness. Endoscopic picture of his tympanic membrane is given below. The red swelling blanches on pressure with the pneumatic speculum. All are true about this condition except?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical features and the picture shown above the diagnosis in this case is glomus tumour.

Glomus is the most common benign tumor of middle ear. It can be located at jugular bulb known as glomus jugular, or it can be located in the middle ear tympanicum.

It arises from para ganglion cells, non hormone-secreting cells (non chromaffin). (Option A)

Clinical features include pulsatile tinnitus, rising red reflex (Option C), brown's sign. It presents as conductive hearing loss and not as sensorineural hearing loss. (Option D)

As it is a benign Tumor usually no metastasis is seen. (Option B)

CT scan is the investigation of choice. Carotid angiography to identify feeding vessels.

Management includes pre op embolization and surgical excision or stereotactic radio surgery.

Key Takeaway:

Glomus Tumor Arising from Non Chromaffin cells arise from Floor of Middle ear gives Rise to Rising Sun Appearance. As it is middle ear Tumor Conductive Hearing loss develops.

Image reference: Dallas ear institute website.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents with left side sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus. On examination there is loss of sensation of posterosuperior part of external auditory canal. His MRI is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical findings and mri picture the diagnosis here is acoustic neuroma.

It is a benign, unencapsulated slow growing tumor. Most common site of origin is Schwann cells of inferior vestibular nerve in IAM.

Clinical features: Hearing loss and tinnitus. Reduced caloric response, anaesthesia over postero-superior part of EAC known as Hitzelberg sign.

Gold standard investigation is MRI.

Management includes Surgical excision by trans- labyrinthine approach. Middle cranial fossa approach is also used. Radiation/Gamma knife in small sized tumor.

Key Takeaway :

Acoustic Neuroma typically occurs at petrous apex giving ice cream cone appearance. Facial nerve involvement leads to loss of anaesthesia at posterosuperior wall of EAC Known as Hitzelberger test is typical.

Image reference: Science direct website.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presented with complaint of bleeding from the ear, progressive deafness and pulsatile tinnitus. On examination there is a red swelling behind the intact tympanic membrane which blanch on pressure with pneumatic speculum. Management includes all except?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical picture and symptoms the diagnosis in this case is Glomus tumour.

Glomus tumour is most common benign tumour of middle ear. It can be located at jugular bulb known as glomus jugular, and at tympanic plexus known as glomus tympanicum.

It is an encapsulated slow growing tumor arising from Para ganglionic cells. Clinical features include pulsatile tinnitus, conductive hearing loss. On examination reddish mass is seen behind intact tympanic membrane giving rising or setting sun appearance.

CT scan is diagnostic showing erosion of jugular plate known as Phelps sign. MRI for intracranial extension shows salt and pepper appearance.

Management includes Preoperative embolization and surgical excision as per Fisch classification. In elderly patients radiotherapy or stereotactic surgery is used. (Options A, C & D)

Option B: Interferon has no role in management of Glomus Tumor. It can be used in Juvenile laryngeal Papillomatosis.

Key Takeaway: Glomus Tumor Management: Along with Preop Embolization

< 3 cm - Stereotactic RadioSurgery

> 3 cm - Surgical Excision.

Image reference: Dallas ear institute.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient is a known case of glomus tumour. His CT Scan showed tumour extending from middle ear to labyrinth and Infra labyrinthine spread up to petrous Apex. It shows significant involvement of the vertical portion of the carotid canal. What will be the grade of this tumour as per Fisch classification?
questions.solution:
Fisch Classification for Glomus Tumor:

Key Takeaway: Summary of Fisch Glomus Tumor Classification.

  1. Middle ear
  2. Mastoid
  3. A. Petrous apex B. Vertical part C. Horizontal part of carotid canal
  4. Intracranial A. <2 cm B. >2cm

Image reference: Research gate journal.
